Whilome in Limehouse docks there dwelt a youth,</br>Childe Higgins hight, the child of curst ennui,</br>Despair, shame, sin, with aye assailing tooth,</br>Had worn his beauty to the bone. — Ah me!</br>A lone unloving libertine was he;</br>For reft of health and hope's delusive wiles,</br>And tossed in youth on passion's stormy sea,</br>He stood a wreck 'mid its deserted isles,</br>Where vainly pleasure wooes and syren woman Smiles.

He was a merchant, 'till ennui'd with toil</br>Of counting house turned but to small account,</br>Sated of home, and Limehouse' leaden soil,</br>Nee more to his dried heart a freshening fount</br>Of kindly feelings; he aspired to mount</br>To intellectual fame, for when the brain</br>Is dulled by thoughts aye fearful to surmount,</br>When youth, hope, love, essay their charms in vain,</br>The rake-hell turns a blue as doth his sky again.

Thus turned the Childe, when in the Morning Post,</br>The Herald, Chronicle, and eke the Times,</br>He read with tasteful glee a daily host</br>Of the Strand bard's self-eulogistic rhymes;</br>He read, and fired with zeal, resolv'd betimes</br>A pilgrim to that minstrel's shrine to move,</br>As Allah's votaries in Arabian climes</br>To far Medina's hallowed altar rove,</br>There low to bend before the idol of their love.

He left his home, his wife without a sigh,</br>And trod with pilgrim-pace the Limehouse road,</br>The morn beamed laughing in the dark blue sky,</br>And warm the sun on post and pavement glowed:</br>Each varied mile new charms and churches showed,</br>But sceptic Higgins jeered the sacred band;</br>For his full tide of thought with scorn o'erflowed,</br>Or deep immersed in objects grave and grand,</br>Dwelt on the Warren's fame, at Number Thirty, Strand.

He passed Whitechapel in such ireful mood,</br>Where murdered muttons bob to every wind;</br>He saw the runnels red with bestial blood,</br>Their lazy streams through street and alley wind:</br>He saw and sickened in his inmost mind,</br>Felt how the heart with savage spleen ycrammed,</br>In blood alone can strange endearment find;</br>But such is man, (each pure affection shammed,)</br>Mean, heartless, lawless, dull, detestable, and damned.

A truce to thought, for attic Billingsgate</br>Already lures the pilgrim from his road;</br>Awe-struck he sees each naiad and her mate,</br>Haggling for halfpence with some river god,</br>Her Doric dialect, beautiful as broad,</br>Her plump cheek redolent of ancient grease,</br>Her fleecy hose with yellow worsted sewed,</br>Recall proud Athen's days, its golden fleece,</br>Its academic wits, and fame that nee shall cease.

Not so thy street, Boeotian Leadenhall!</br>Famed for new novels, leaden all and dull</br>Though wags thy library "Minerva" call,</br>Yet very British is Minerva's skull.—</br>Her brainless books seem'd doom'd to gather wool,</br>Or sold to vile cheesemongers by the pound,</br>To scour the soulless sculleries of John Bull,</br>While pots and pans (not sylvan) aye surround</br>Each panic-stricken tome, despite its lore profound.

And this is fame, that covetous cooks' shops</br>Should form the graves of every martyr'd work,</br>That Southey's strains should wrap up mutton chops,</br>Or Cheshire cheese anoint the leaves of Burke.—</br>That Theodore Ducas — Catiline — should lurk</br>'Mid Granger's sweets, with Wordsworth's Peter Bell,</br>Or Chalmers's Lecture on the Scotish kirk</br>Sleep with its fathers in some London hell,</br>Some fruiterer's fruitful shelf where dirt and dulness dwell.

But, lo, th' Exchange!  a busy world is here,—</br>A world of knaves in wide confusion blent;</br>Here beams the smile, — there falls th' unheeded tear,</br>For stock well-purchased, or for gold ill-spent.</br>All are on one fool's errand madly bent,</br>And Turk and Christian pass unnoticed by,</br>While Israel's sons nee more to discontent</br>A prey, — the new Jerusalem espy,</br>In this barbaric booth, this fair of vanity.

Ah me!  how grovelling is the mind of man!</br>How fixed on perishable hopes, and mean!</br>Wealth, honor, pride, engross his paltry span</br>Of life, — then leave him scathed in heart as mien.—</br>Here where I stand, the spirit of the scene</br>Enchains all hearts with talismanic spell,</br>In vain aspiring youth with blossoms green,</br>Bedeck'd comes forth; — here Mammon tolls his knell,—</br>And round him weaves the chain of avarice and of hell.

Th' Exchange is past, the Mansion House appears,</br>Surpris'd the Childe surveys its portly site,</br>Dim dreams assail him of convivial years,</br>And keener waxes his blunt appetite.—</br>Luxurious visions whelm his fancy quite,</br>Of calipash and eke of calipee,</br>While sylphs of twenty stone steal o'er his sight,</br>Smiting their thighs with blythe Apician glee,</br>And licking each his lips right beautiful to see.

Twas here they tucked, — these unctuous city sprites,—</br>'Twas here like geese they fattened and they died,</br>Here turtle reared for them her keen delights,</br>And forests yielded their cornuted pride.—</br>But all was vain, 'mid daintiest feasts they sighed;</br>Gout trod in anger on each hapless toe;</br>Stern apoplexy pummelled each fat side,</br>And dropsy seconded his deadly blow,</br>'Till floored by fate they sunk to endless sleep below.

But hark, the hum of multitudes, the roar</br>Of carts and coaches, and the various squalls</br>Or cries, that pierce the ear-drum's inmost core,</br>Have roused the Childe's attention at Saint Paul's.</br>Cheapside to near Guildhall in thunder calls,</br>Guildhall replies, of lungs with justice proud;</br>Milk-street and Lothbury, glad to join the brawls,</br>Have found a tongue, while Wood-street from her shroud</br>Rebellows to Lad-lane, who calls to her aloud.

And in the midst, as leader of the band,</br>Stands the magnificent Saint Paul's; — he towers</br>Sublime to heaven, by winnowing breezes fanned,</br>Unknown on lower earth; — the rattling showers,</br>The storm, the whirlwind that in vengeance lowers,</br>Pass him unharm'd; — he lifts his giant brow,</br>As if in mockery of their puny powers,</br>Or rapt in clouds like conscious guilt in woe,</br>Soars from the vulgar ken a mystery as now.

Something too much of this; but now 'tis past,</br>And Fleet-street spreads her busy vale below:</br>Lo!  proud ambitious gutters hurry past,</br>To rival Thames in full continuous flow;</br>The Inner Temple claims attention now,</br>That Golgotha of thick and thread-bare skulls,</br>Where modest merit pines in chambers low,</br>And impudence his oar in triumph pulls</br>Along the stream of wealth, and snares its rich sea-gulls.

Hail to this shrine of barristers and brass!</br>Of wigs and wags of learning and of lead!</br>Solomon's brazen temple — but alas!</br>With old king Log, king Solomon instead.</br>Ye gifted spirits of the legal dead,</br>Will none arise to grace degraded law?</br>Vain hope, despite the lore of each long head,</br>Satan hath found their lives a moral flaw,</br>And on them, bailiff-like, hath laid his ebon paw.

And thus the world is rife alone with fools,</br>Who clank in chains while fashion holds the noose;</br>Court, camp, and church, — what are they but the tools</br>Of sin, shame, slang, buffoonery, and abuse?</br>Momus with man has made a lasting truce.</br>And hence our patriots puff, — our warriors bray,—</br>Hence critics flood us with a muddy sluice</br>Of maudlin prose, — hence cant holds sovereign sway,</br>And sinless saints are spurn'd, while sainted sinners pray.

Our life is one fierce fever — death the leech</br>Who lulls each throb; — the has been, and to be;</br>The sole divine whose welcome aid can teach</br>The mysteries of a dread futurity.—</br>Come when he may, his advent will to me</br>Be spring and sunshine, for my soul is dark,</br>And o'er the billows of life's shoreless sea,</br>A sea uncheer'd by hope's celestial ark,</br>Cradled in storms and winds floats lone my little bark.

Thus mused the Childe, as thoughtful he drew near</br>The sacred shrine of Number Thirty, Strand,</br>And saw bright glittering in the hemisphere—</br>Like stars on moony nights — a sacred band</br>Of words that formed the bard's cognomen grand</br>Each letter shone beneath the eye of day,</br>And the proud sign-boot, by spring breezes fanned,</br>Shot its deep brass reflections o'er the way,</br>As shoots the tropic morn o'er meads of Paraguay.

Childe Higgins hied him to this bless'd abode—</br>Not forked Parnassus — Crete's Olympian hill—</br>Not Ilium's plain — by kings and warriors trod—</br>Calypso's cavern, Aganippe's rill,</br>Or Circe's isle famed for enchantment still—</br>Ere thrilled his soul with such intense delight</br>As thrilled it now when Warren's magic till</br>Thro' each shop-window gleamed upon his sight,</br>Clear as Italian dawn that gilds the brow of night.

But I forget — my pilgrim's shrine is won—</br>And he himself — the lone unloving Childe—</br>His Limehouse-birth, his name, his sandal-shoon,</br>And scallop shell, are dreams by fancy piled,</br>His dull despairing thoughts alone — once mild</br>As love — now dark as fable's darkest hell,</br>Are stern realities; — but o'er the wild</br>Drear desert of their blight the soothing spell</br>Of Warren's verse flits rare as sun-beams o'er Pall Mall.

Farewell — a word that must be and hath been—</br>Ye dolphin dames who turn from blue to grey,</br>Ye dandy drones who charm each festive scene</br>With brainless buzz, and frolic in your May,</br>Ye ball-room bards who live your little day,</br>And ye who flushed in purse parade the town,</br>Booted or shod — to you my Muse would say,</br>"Buy WARREN'S BLACKING," as ye hope to crown</br>Your senseless souls or soulless senses with renown.</br>
